description:
Officially my fav coffee shop in San Fran. On so many levels: 
- baked goods are all mouth watering
- beverages tasty and creative 
- ambiance and decor is "fresh" and modern
- clientele feels like my kind of community!

Thank you!
author: Mitch J.

description:
Came in for my afternoon coffee and to hang out while reading my new book. Was a little surprised when I ordered the brew coffee to stay and with tax it was only $1.08 !  For a trendy triangular coffee roaster in the center of it all ... Market St & Castro. Turns out, it's National Coffee Day. Coffee is only a dollar all day.

It's worth it even at the regular $3 a mug. 

Enjoy, great space to hang out, people watch and get wired on fresh roasted coffee!
author: John H.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker at all, but needed something to wake me up on my morning walk. The space is aesthetically pleasing with a lot of natural light, which freshens up the setting. They have plenty of plants instilled around the sleek countertops --very neat space and design. I just had a cup of Chai with Almond Milk ($4.25) to-go and was on my way.

This isn't the best place to study or work though as there isn't too much space though. On the other hand, great to people watching as it's situated on a corner with floor to ceiling glass windows all around.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Verve Coffee Roasters is a small, minimal space that offers your typical coffee options as well as some nice light food choices. My boyfriend and I stopped here one morning during our visit to SF to fuel up for the day. I ordered a latte and a piece of quiche, and he got a pour over and the daily toast, which had ricotta and plenty of greens. The guy at the counter was super friendly, helpful, and patient, which was refreshing as I find sometimes the customer service at places like this can be lacking. 

The pour over came with a little card that includes the variety's flavor profile notes, cup characteristics, producer, region, process, and cultivar. I'm not a coffee snob by any means but I still thought this was cool. The latte was your typical latte, creamy and delicious. My personal favorite part of our visit was the quiche. When I ordered, I was informed that the slices are served at room temp and asked if that was okay, which I really appreciated. The quiche was so intensely creamy and rich that it almost felt more like a dessert, which sounds weird but it was packed with flavor from the salty bacon and so decadent. Definitely not an every day option for me but a nice vacation treat. The daily toast was just okay, not a whole lot of flavor and I thought it could have used more seasoning. Overall I enjoyed our stop at Verve and would go back in the future, or if I lived nearby.
author: Katy C.

description:
I consistently have a great experience here. The service is outstanding. Friendly yet unpretentious. The vibe is local with a mix of friends meeting friends, first dates, people working, and people getting a quick drink. It's also a great place to people watch. 

Menu is more traditional with brewed coffee, cold brew, espresso drinks, and tea. 

I would highly recommend the pastries that are sourced locally. Or the made in house food. The menu is small, but has some great healthy options.
author: Alan H.

description:
Verve has been one of my favorite coffee experiences on my latest trip to SF.

The aesthetic of the cafe includes large windows on most sides and awesome use of lines, light wood, and touches of teal. Love the pop of color. Simple and effective. The counter is long and gives the coffee a front-and-center placement. Not a crazy amount of seating but does include a small communal table and benches and low tables, allowing the coffee culture to shine. It's really a unique space.

I went for a Gibraltar, which is espresso plus a splash of warm milk. (It's like a mini latte!) A bit pricey but definitely satisfying and delicious. The barista offered to add more milk orvchange the temperature of milk if we wanted. Not sure how he would have done the latter, but he obviously cares a about a customized cup.

There is a small but ample selection of sweet and savory carby foods. The open-face sandwiches, in particular, looked very pretty and tasty.
author: Jess L.

description:
If I'm not mistaken - and I often am - this is Verve's only retail presence in the city, and it's a prominent spot at the much traversed corner of Market and Church. Most of their cafes are in Santa Cruz, where co-founders Ryan O'Donovan and Colby Barr base their operations, and Tokyo of all places, where I think I saw one of their cafes in Shinjuku. In other words, they may be Blue Bottling toward Starbucks territory but there was no evidence of racial profiling yet at the Castro location. Just more of a preference for them to serve the local hipster populace from what I could tell from their droning chatter.

I suppose I should have gone for one of their coffee specialties since they appeared to have all the shiny hardware necessary to prepare them (photo: http://bit.ly/2JkpKSO). However, I was in the mood for tea on a blustery day when I was a bit on the forlorn side. I went for a $4 cup of their Rooibos which was advertised as having elements of caramel and nectar and being 'bodied' whatever that means. I waited patiently for the barista to prepare it from a jar of loose leaves, and the result was smooth and, well, 'bodied' (photo: http://bit.ly/2Hl167X). There is seating in here, but good luck with that as the laptoppers lay siege to the space. In response, I was off on my merry way.

TEA - 4 stars...a particularly smooth Rooibos can be sipped here
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...ah, to be young and self-entitled
SERVICE - 3 stars...tersely pleasant
TOTAL - 4 stars...probably helps to express some nerve at Verve
author: Ed U.

description:
To be honest, I came for the coffee but I stayed for the stoked feels. What I loved most about Verve Coffee Roasters in San Francisco was how the interior design and colour palette gave the whole place an atmosphere of California's surf culture. Instantly, I got a breath of the Santa Cruz lifestyle.

Read my full review at: http://thefoodi.com/verve-coffee-roasters/
author: Gaby D.

description:
Decent lattes. Had a new barista working on our drinks. 3 of 4 lattes were overflowing the cup. Although the coffee actually tasted good, there was no need to over-pour 3 of 4 drinks. Rookie mistake I guess?
Good coffee. Decent vibe. Lousy seating (dumb mini wooden tables.. or are they chairs?)
Great spot to grab coffee on the go, but not a great spot to just chill.
author: JonJon W.

description: Great coffee, friendly service. There's not too many coffee shops in the area actually so I wanted to try this one. There's not much space to come in and do work so keep that in mind. They offer a lavender latte which is unique and special. They do have food too; croissants that looked amazing
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
VERVE is a FAVE. Being from the Monterey area, and also passionate about quality coffee...Verve is a must.
I was so happy when they opened this site in San Francisco. 
The experience is continued every time, and I also love the oatmeal. I've had it there, and to-go. So Tasty.
author: Amy O.

description:
Verve has some great caffeinated drinks in a really cool space in the Castro District.  The company is originally from Santa Cruz and I hope that like it can spread the gospel to distant cities like Philz and Blue Bottle Coffee.

I recommend getting the bowl of soul with English Breakfast which is basically an elevated tea latte.  It's pretty busy so it's not easy to get a seat and the staff is very friendly.  I'm only dinging points because I saw some flies hovering around the pastries but that was hopefully just a one time thing.
author: Mark C.

description:
Tried the Verve in Santa Cruz and loved it. Discovered there was a location in San Francisco so decided to make a pit stop before heading to Bernal Heights Park (look for my review of that soon). Went here at 5pm on a Sunday. 

I'm most familiar with the Mission Bay area so the Castro is still relatively new to me. I'm not sure if it's right but the Verve building seemed to fit in - then again, keeping the brick exterior helps. 

Cleanliness (4/5): very thing I noticed when I walked in was the well-stocked and clean pastry case. Condiment bar is stocked and clean as well. While I was sitting, a barista came by the tables to pick up used cups and plates. 

Customer Connection (3/5): cashier was friendly and nice. Nothing exceptional. 

Service/Product Quality (4/5): ordered an Iced Coffee and it was delicious! Most iced coffees i've tried need a little bit of cream or sugar because of a strong burnt flavor or acidity. This one didn't.  I forgot to ask which blend it is. I wish there was more complexity though.
author: Martin N.

description:
I would probably give Verve somewhere between 3 and 4 stars (until Yelp changes it's rating system, it is what it is).  This Verve outpost replaced a former optometry office, and the cafe has an airy and open atmosphere that suggests this part of Market Street is prime real estate. I waked in during a weekday and thought there was ample seating for people working on their computers, chatting with friends, or just sitting down to read or hang out. 

This might just be my personal preference, but the lack of desks and massive windows that look out to the sidewalk would not make this an ideal workspace. However, I have liked Verve coffee in the past and would visit this place again. The one menu item that I wouldn't repeat is their sweetened cold brew coffee drink, which felt too cloyingly sweet to me.
author: Keith H.

description:
Hands down the most delicious coffee in California, if not the United States. So unbelievably happy this place opened up in SF and hoping many more open soon. I recommend starting with a hot coffee and skipping the cold coffee until you really need an energy jolt. If you are looking for beans to take home, definitely try as many as you can, but as one of the barista's said to me, "Sermon is a power house". If you do not know what I mean, I mean that Sermon is by far the best coffee to take home. 

The only con of this location is that there are like two outlets, so make sure you have a portable charger before you decide to work on a computer here.
author: James S.

description: Um sure it's good quality coffee, but why is it worth $15 to get a hot and ready coffee just poured into a cup and an avocado toast taken off the toast? I thought the egg came with it, but when I asked what is gluten free on the menu the cashier told me the avocado toast could be served in a bowl and pointed at the sample of toast with a poached egg on top. I decided to get it and she asked if I wanted an egg, which was confusing cause I thought it came with it so I sad yes! Over $15 later I got a cup of prepaid coffee and a fish bowl with an egg and avocado. The bowl was good but not over $10 good. Coffee didn't taste particularly good either.
author: Samira I.

description:
Top 10 cold brew for me! Try the steel cut brûlée oatmeal ... good portion and tasty. 

One downside (like many coffee shops) is that all the seats were taken by people with laptops. Would like to have stayed for a while.
author: Janelle K.

description:
Best coffee I have ever had.  Seriously.  And the girls behind the counter helping us were so wonderful...  exactly what I wanted is what I got.  
Highly recommend this spot for an amazing morning cup of coffee!!
author: Carly M.

description:
Had a great breakfast there -avocado, radishes (several types) oil, salt, whole grain bread and a perfectly cooked soft center egg. Topped it off with a  delicious cortado. 
Also got some ground dark roast to go, and enjoying it at home. Excellent quality.
author: Dan B.

description:
I love these folks. They are always friendly and real when they take your order. The coffee drinks are A+ quality. The food is delicious, beautiful, and well thought out. The seating is cozy and communal. The vibe is techies working but also creative and interesting people just chatting. 
Go Verve!!
author: Taylor P.

description: Great place to stop by and grab a coffee on the go or hangout and read a book or work on your laptop. Always enjoy their drip coffee of the day roast and the handcrafted espresso bar beverages are awesome! Seating space is mostly communal and somewhat limited depending on the time of day.
author: Derwood A.

description: Very small space, I expected there'd be a second floor. Staff was pretty pretentious and Rude. When you ever get a chance to visit Brooklyn New York, you can check out Devocion. Devocion is the best example how those coffee shop should be.
author: Myron L.

description:
I would like to amend my review because the management did reach out when they saw my earlier reivew. They even offered a credit, but I would be willing to come back with out it! As I said before their coffee and the ambiance were not the issue, and it was just a customer service issue. 

They immediately recognized the issue and changed their approach. I understand that they are trying to prevent stragglers from using their bathrooms needlessly but also trying to avoid profiling people. Hopefully they were able to come up with a good medium. Thank you for reaching out!
author: Mike C.

description:
Drip coffee was good, but a little steep in price. My wife got a Cortado and it was very good. Atmosphere was nothing like I had ever seen; it was awesome! Staff was very kind and had good knowledge about their coffee offerings. The only way that Verve could have gotten 5 stars is if I wouldn't have left their cafe covered in dog hair from their benches.

I would go back for Espresso over drip/manual coffees, but would think twice before going to do homework or reading because it's not so clean.
author: Grayson W.

description:
Cute vibe...delicious cookies...BUT really watered down lattes...

Ordered a coffee, an almond mil klatte, and a chocolate walnut cookie for a friend.

My friend raved about her cookie and didn't say much about the coffee. 

For me, my almond latte sucked. It had no coffee flavor and tasted like almond milk. Is there a half espresso shot used here instead of two shots? Really terrible latte.

Will not return; Four Barrel will continue to be my go-to in the area.
author: Monica J.

description: The Rio Grande roast was a great recommendation by the barista working that day. As a newbie to Verve I had only tried the blends 1950 and Streetcar, but I wanted to try a single origin bean. 2 weeks in it's a great roast I'd suggest picking up for your pour over.
author: Deborah B.

description:
I think this place has potential to be really great. The atmosphere is awesome and it's well decorated. And my iced latte was pretty good.

BUT..............

-1 star for having crappy seating. The benches were extremely uncomfortable and there's only one table.
-1 star because I was jealous another guy got his drink in a mason jar where as I had just an ugly plain pint glass.

I would probably come again for the iced latte, but wouldn't necessarily hang out here. Also, the avo/egg toast looks bomb - might try that one day!
author: Angela L.

description: When visiting friends in San Fran, we went here almost every morning that we were in town! As soon as we walked in I swooned- the aesthetic of this place is to die for. Seriously, bless whoever designed this place, because it is beautiful. And of course the coffee was good! The espresso is top notch, and the iced lavender latte was one of the best that I've had. The monkey bread is also definitely worth ordering. I'm looking forward to coming back on my next visit to San Francisco!
author: Brianna N.

description:
Let me start, I love Verve Coffee. I've been to numerous ones all over the state of California and love the vibe and the food. It can be a bit more, but you know the quality is good.

This location is easy to find and the service is friendly. I think we spent more time picking out beans to take home than actually deciding on what we wanted.
author: Amanda L.

description: An iced vanilla coffee is my go-to drink at Verve.  This location has comfortable seating areas.  Parking it tough to find.
author: Diane T.

description: Yes SF is filled with great coffee shops. What I really like about this one besides great coffee and eats to go with, is it's a bit roomier, has more tables and seating area. I like the more relaxed vibe. I don't have to worry there won't be anywhere to sit or feel like I'm being rushed to get out. Yay Verve!
author: Karen R.

description:
I tried this place a few times and found the coffee to just be ok. I had the "flavor" latte which is kind of their own flavor syrup which is decent. Tastes sort of like a vanilla latte. 

The location is clean and modern but has sort of the mission hipster coffee joint vibe going on. And the coffee is pretty expensive compared to other local joints.

I gave it a few tries but I think I have other favorites in the hood that I'll be frequenting instead.
author: Chris D.

description:
Love this coffee shop. Delicious, rich espresso drinks. They also have tea which they time the steep to perfection for you as well.

I avoid ordering the baked goods here. Have seen some flies going in and out of the pastries.
author: Steven W.

description: Although the place is quite pricey, the atmosphere is calm and relaxing. I find it a good place to relax and drink your coffee while you study, read, or rest. The customer service is great and kind. They even congratulated me on my graduation. I was so thankful.
author: Leo C.

description:
I'm a big fan of Verve and have always stopped by their Santa Cruz locations when I'm in that neck of the woods. Now that Verve is in the Bay Area, I had to stop by.

For a very rainy day around lunchtime, the place was packed. A majority of the people there were on their laptops... my wife and I weren't able to sit. Later on, we ended up sitting on the planter near the entrance. The ambiance is minimalist and bright, with light wood accents throughout. The staff was welcoming and friendly. For some reason, it didn't quite feel like the Santa Cruz locations (maybe more artwork and plants are needed?). I had a latte and that was on point!
author: Josh L.

description:
In a dog-saturated neighborhood this is the most elitist, anti-dog coffee establishment Ive come across in the city.  I'm all about health guidelines and applying same rules for all, but at least install something for owners to tie their dogs up if you want to get any of their business.  You're 2 blocks from the best dog park in the city!  But instead they shoo you away like they probably do to the vagrants.    

This review is not even considering that $20 you'll be out for toast and a tiny coffee.
author: Bryce C.

description:
Wasted trip here to get a decent latte. Drank 1/3 and tossed the remaining 2/3.

The verve +'s:
+ Prompt service and courteous.

The lethargy -'s:
- WEAK lattes for $4.75. So much foam and no coffee taste. This place is about coffee so this is a big miss. My partner's latte was much of the same.

I came here to get some verve and left with none. Go somewhere else.
author: Yiven C.

description: I've only ever gotten a cold brew or latte to go, but the coffee has been great each time.
author: Jay M.

description: I got a soy chai latte and was impressed. It had spice and wasn't loaded with sugar. :)
author: Tenzin K.

description:
Full disclosure: I'm rating this location based on it's coffee and it's work space.

I ordered a cappuccino with almond milk and it came out to $5 (almond milk was $1 extra). The cappuccino was creamy and the espresso had a deep, roasted coffee flavor. It was a little bitter but I added a little bit of sugar and it was perfect.

The space doesn't lend itself to folks who wish to work here on their laptops very well. It's a large space littered with windows which allows ample light to stream in and lends itself to great people watching. Unfortunately, there is only one communal table that fits ~8 people with laptops. Towards the back of the store they have padded benches with coffee tables.
author: Angelina H.

description: Great coffee spot for a quick snack or a nook to read. Posted up here to enjoy an afternoon break and wasn't disappointed. Their drip coffee was great and the staff was extremely friendly.
author: Emily L.

description: Cute joint, good coffee, rude employee. I was there this week and I sat down before ordering to check my emails and get settled, well one of the ladies working there thought it would be a good idea to "wipe" down the table im on and make it obvious that she didn't want me there not knowing i was a returning customer who needed a few minutes before ordering. I usually like going to this location but she got me confused with WiFi hogs. Better judgement next time wont hurt not everyone walks in and orders off jump.
author: Karlos G.

description:
Rating for service and kombucha! This is my first visit - will need more before I can give a 5-Star rating. 

The WiFi is decent - faster than Whole Foods. 

Interior space is bright and comfortable to work in. Not a quiet environment so bring your headphones if music disturbs you. I appreciate the live plants. 

Their merchandise is pro-earth in the sense that they promote conserving resources. I dig that. 

I'll have to come back for their food and coffee next time!
author: Tammy H.

description: The croissants are fresh (we got almond and chocolate). The honey lavender drink is incredible!
author: Rocio B.

description: Obviously there are a lot of great places to get coffee in San Francisco. I frequent Temple, Blue bottle etc. This was probably the best cappuccino I ever had today. Smooth and great coffee flavor. Bravo Verve!
author: Richard A.

description: Hot chocolate was really good. That being said, there wasn't enough whipped cream. Yes, I understand the need for artistic expression, but whipped cream shouldn't be barely a line spanning half the mug when it comes to hot chocolate. Furthermore, there was no seating available and where there were bar tables there were no seats.
author: Batya M.

description: They had a Whiskey Latte I thought was really good. It had some of the barrel aged flavor that you get from stouts/porters that get that kind of treatment. I went back recently and it was wasn't on the menu. I wouldn't go here to hang out or get work done. Seating is kind of cramped and there are people coming in an out of the shop.
author: Huey N.

description:
Artisanal coffee before 7am in the Mission is hard to find. (What's up with that? Isn't coffee typically a beverage consumed in the morning? There are a lot of people out in the world at that time. [/rant])

Thankfully Verve decided to differentiate a bit with a 6am open time. 

Aesthetics are great but be warned - first time visit is probably going to require some Yelp research or a bit of conversation with the staff. They have a slightly hard to decode drink menu, featuring several house specialty beverages requiring inquiry. The food menu requires discovery at the counter (but they do serve fresh food which is a plus) and the pastries in the display case are neither labeled nor visibly priced. 

These usability issues aside, the food and drink here is really good! Mocha at Four Barrel still takes my vote for best in SF (it's that ground up Dandelion chocolate), but this one is probably the next best around. The whipped cream topping is both beautiful and tasty. 

Several other reviewers have mentioned the Manresa pastries. It's surprising they chose to import baked goods with Thoroughbread just doors down but if you want the taste of a Michelin rated Los Gatos restaurant brand without having to actually go there, this is one way to do it. Kouign amann (served in slices rather than individually) is competitive with the B Patisserie in taste and texture; also has the clear advantage of being way less messy to eat. The monkey bread is on the crunchier side but I like it better this way than mostly tasting like a cinnamon roll. Both are worth ordering at least once, but know in doing it, you're signing yourself up for a $5 snack. 

Seating is a bit like hanging out a friends house - there's a dining room table like space and several bench like couches oriented around coffee tables. This is fine - and downright relaxing - for early morning coffee stop but having seen large crowds in here on weekends, I might recommend avoiding it during peak work or coffee social times.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Verve roasts excellent coffee, but tbh, I cried a little when the girl at the register rang me up for a $6 single cup of coffee. That's really my only gripe with Verve--the prices seem excessive, even for an excessively pricey city. 

Gripes aside, they have a really nice space and serve top notch coffee. Like most SF coffee shops, it's a bit on the small side, so it may be difficult to find space if you intend to work on a laptop there. They've got nice plant friends inside and killer branding, both of which appeal to a nerd like me.

Oh, and they've got a whiskey latte on the menu. So, game over. Go to Verve for that, if nothing else.
author: Fiona F.

description: Delicious coffee, friendly staff and neat environment. This place is simply the best.
author: Dan Mark D.

description:
Love verve, the coffee is always good. Pretty pricey so just keep that in mind before entering. The design is not like the Santa Cruz shops but very unique, bright and happy. The staff is always so friendly. I went at 6 pm on a Tuesday so the parking meter out front was free and the shop was relatively empty. 

$5.5 for a mocha.
author: Cheyenne T.

description: Really enjoyed the coffee here. That said, it was VERY crowded and everyone was on a laptop working on something and listening to music. Not a very social vibe, and too hard to fight for seating. Don't know that this will become my new go-to place, even though the coffee is quite nice.
author: Sean B.

description:
Fix your Wifi and fire that tall, thin guy with short hair of yours.

I was in the neighborhood and looking for a place to send out some emails after my interview. So took a chance and went with Verve over the Starbucks a few min walk from there spot. 

Order their 'Bowl in the Soul' which was frothy soy milk with chai leaves. Not bad for 5 bucks. 

But their Wifi sucked. I tried connecting and after 10 attempts went to ask for help to the folks behind the counter. The guy didn't give a damn about my request, smiled and just ran while playing on his phone. 

When I told him "Your wifi probably doesn't work." He said he knew that. And when I said "That sucks", he smiled back again and went back to his phone while biting on his sandwich.

Finally, before I left their roaster, I asked the guy again if he knew any Starbucks close by. He responded negatively and made it clear that he didn't give a damn about the customer.

Luckily, there's a Starbucks 2 min walk from here. So unless you're cool with being treated like s#&t, I would not step foot inside Verve Coffee Roasters.

PS: If I were the owner, I would replace that guy with someone with more empathy and compassion (aka EQ).
author: Ankur S.

description: First things first. Great spot for single origin coffee. Second, lovely space, comfortable decor, and friendly staff.  Received amazing service.  For example, there was a mixup of the drink order.  Matt offered a replacement drink. I declined. He later approached me and offered a free cup on the next visit.  Rest of the staff were great as well.  Easy  to access via muni. Must try!
author: Jenna J.

description:
You know how long I've waited for Verve to be in the Bay Area? Santa Cruz was just too far for me. I was so excited the news of the SF location. For a while, I got my Verve fix from the Fremont Whole Foods because they happened to sell Verve beans. At work, we bring in different beans and Verve has consistently been one of our top faves!

Now that I live in SF, Verve is much closer - so yay for easy access to beans AND drinks! The location is pretty easy to once you are on the Muni - it's off of Market and right near the Church Station. Whenever I'm near the area, I would stop by for a latte and a little snack if I feel a little fancy (food is a little pricey...but I guess that's SF for you).

The decor is nice and it has a pretty open space. The bathroom is spacious and usually clean. There is wifi if anyone is interested in that. Seating is a bit hard, but there are areas where you can stand and enjoy your drink. This is a great place to not only enjoy coffee, but to catch up with friends or do a bit of work (if you are lucky to get a seat!).

Staff is pretty nice and chill! I was surprised that one of the baristas remembered me after one visit a few weeks ago. Either she had really good memory, or I must be very memorable. ;)
author: Danni N.

description: Another hot spot for coffee lovers. I love their pour over coffee and their nitro cold brew. This place serves breakfast and pastries by Manresa bread, which is a plus. Gluten free options are available (try the gluten free chocolate cake with candied orange or the carrot cake!) For those who don't like coffee, this place serves a great selection of teas too!
author: Sam M.

description: This cafe is close to my apartment and I like starting my day here. I often visit this place and the stuff know my favourite kind of coffee. They have a big selection of coffee, which you can buy online. Also you can meet interesting people here. Nice decorations. Simple, but at the same time my favorite cafe.
author: Dean A.

description:
We get Verve at work for drip coffee and it tastes okay so I decided to stop by for a latte and a pastry because Thoroughbread was closed for the holidays. I ordered an almond latte and an almond croissant. First thing I noticed as I was ordering the pastry was that the pastry box was full of flies, so I felt kind of gross about the pastry I ordered but figured I can toast it up or something when I get home. The almond croissant was okay, not too sweet which I liked but it was also pretty bland. The latte was actually the most disappointing thing for me because I couldn't taste the coffee at all. It just tastes like warm milk.

I walk by here all the time and it looks like a good place to work and people watch, but probably not coming in again.
author: Youri P.

description: Amazing service, delicious kale pie & the coffee! Love love this place. Very hip place, cool music & the staff are super friendly
author: Taryn M.

description: I've been here twice. Good coffee, solid pastries. Both times though, the service has left something to be desired. The representative example was today - we arrived 5 minutes before closing. Understandably, later than I would usually walk into an establishment. But the door was still open, people still inside, and staff still present. We walk inside and ask for the simplest of orders - tea! Just hot water and a tea bag. And the response is: we've had a really long day so we can't help you. Very disappointing - can't recommend Verve with other options around.
author: Sean T.

description:
Pros: Great corner coffee place that's easy to find and you get in and out pretty quick.  You have a good selection of pastries.  The drink flavors are unique blends and I got whatever is the closest to French Vanilla and it was great.  The closest flavor to hazelnut turned out really good as well and we keep coming back. 

Cons:  Not a lot of spaces to work, but a small bench area to sit and talk. There is only 1 drink size, which is about 12 oz.  Drinks are made with care and sometimes can take a couple of minutes, but we never waited long.

Overall, recommend because the coffee was great, service was friendly and easy to find!
author: Mee-Jin Y.

description: Just paid $6.50 for a jasmine green tea to go in a small cup. Wow!! It took ten minutes to make. I just don't understand how it can cost so much. Even the most expensive coffee shops charge $4 for the same thing. I plan to boycott this place and go around the corner to Thorough Bread.
author: K E.

description: Delicious avocado toast, and perfectly brewed coffee! A must stop for a quick breakfast or coffee. There is limited seating of course but it's comfortable and very inviting. I didn't try the baked goods, but wish I had!
author: Jen A.

description:
Ahhhhh, finally! A Verve coffee in my hometown!!!! I have been a huge fan of Verve ever since I lived in LA. I also love how Verve started out in Santa Cruz of all places. I'm so glad they opened one in my hometown of SF! HOORAY!

Their Bowl of Soul is always great, but today I got the latte. I just love how their coffee is smooth and tasty. They also serve pastries here from Manresa (3-star Michelin restaurant in Los Gatos). Chocolate croissant was decent but not the best I ever had. I also got a prosciutto sandwich, which was delicious but there was too much bread to prosciutto ratio. And bring floss too - prosciutto gets stuck in your teeth, ya know? Not exactly the best item to order for a first date.

Service is excellent here. I met a worker there named Nathaniel today, and he asked me how I liked my latte when I bussed my coffee mug back, and genuinely cared! Ambiance is beautiful - lovely wooden paneling just like all the other locations. The place with filled with hipsters and techies. Sigh....as a registered nurse working in healthcare, I #dontBelong. Regardless, I will still return. So happy Verve has made its way to SF!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
This corner of Market was basically made for a Verve. By 2018, I expect to never be farther than 200 feet from a Wave dripper when I'm on Market Street. No complaints, necessarily. 

For a new joint, things ran pretty smoothly even after like, what? A week in operation? It would probably be very cozy and, uh, "hygge" if it wasn't packed completely to the gills. (It's gonna be packed completely to the gills on a weekend mornings for... a while, I bet. They moved through a big honkin' line in good time and it didn't take too long to grab your order.

Grabbed some beans, a drip (which, yeah, I saw the crazy expensive and definitely delicious pourover set-up they had and said "Nah, maybe next time" because sometimes I make bad decisions), and avocado toast, because it seemed like I'd never come by a more appropriate time to try avocado toast. 

The secret of avocado toast is tons and tons of butter. It was delicious. The coffee was great, too.
author: Jim M.

description: As I got off the J Church streetcar near Market St., I walked across towards what used to be Veo Optics until it has been replaced by a brand spanking new coffee bar in an acute V-shape area.  What's interesting about the new cafe is the same capital letter V.  The coffee bar's interior is filled with positive energy, warm hospitality, and very healthy coffee choices better than Blue Bottle Coffee, given its appropriate name, VERVE.  Even though I'm not a fan of coffee, there is one drink that catches my eye, and that's chai tea latte.  Why chai?  Because chai is tea while Gibraltar and Machiatto are both coffee.  I tried coffee once, but it's an acquired taste I barely consume.  If there's no chai, then I go for any tea options.  Sandwiches are fine, but I'm in a mood for tea.  Hopefully, this coffee bar shall never be replaced by another company with the same capital letter V.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
I'm generally not a fan of coffee spots where staff seem deliberately slow and disinterested in an ever-growing line.  Today with about 8 ppl in line one worker was sweeping cookie crumbs off the counter. . .instead of helping _anyone_ else w a drink or food order. 

Cashiers are often taking a whole lot of time to process a simple drink order. . .im not saying they need to rush like they are putting out a fire, just maybe acknowledge that ppl have more plans for their days / life than waiting in line for no good reason. 

They would do better as a business if they met customer needs faster. 

The coffee is good/ok but so should ANY cup overpriced above $3. Please don't be a San Francisco w overpriced everything and dullenial attitude. FWIW can get organic coffee at New Leaf for $2-$4 and less pretentious and _healthier- breakfast for less, and nicer, real staff.
author: Doula S.

description:
I've been a fan of Verve Coffee for some tome so I was excited that SF got it's first location! Coffee was great as usual snd the cafe design was really nice a lot of room to sit or stand but not enough for those who want to plop down the laptop and work or a paper and pen. There was just one table for such an activity, it's communal for about 6-8 folks. It feels like a design for when people used to actually talk to one another at cafes so make if that what you will. 
The staff was eager, the coffee was dope
author: Tommy W.

description: I've been here twice now and would say it's pretty good. Not amazing, but pretty good! I really like that they have a variety of flavors and drinks like whiskey syrup, and a vanilla-like syrup to choose from. The only downside I would say is that their drinks taste like they have a lot of milk in them and it takes away from the espresso taste. Maybe they should put one more shot into them ;)
author: Daniel C.

description: The worst avocado toast I've ever had in SF. Almost threw it up because of how salty it was. Oh and overprice coffee that doesn't taste so well. I don't plan on coming back.
author: Edgar H.

description: The coffee is pretty good here. I think the only downside is there isn't much seating at a table. The couches at the far right though are pretty cute and conducive for doing work!
author: Edson M.

description:
Lovely spot to grab a cup and a pastry. Nice decor, next to muni for my commute, and even some seating for those who want to work.

Very hygge in the middle of a rainy few months.
author: Mike I.

description: The coffee is pricy - but it's delicious. The ambiance is fantastic and the staff are all welcoming personable and friendly. This is the ideal cozy coffee shop on the corner.
author: Mara H.

description:
We used to have a lovely little cafe (Sofie) on 16th near my house that served Verve that left partially due to opening this shop, so I was glad when they finally opened.

I've had a few nice lattes there and yesterday decided to have an Americano, which had always been my go-to and consistent at Sofie.

The barista handed me a horrifically sour beverage. Although I was furious, I kindly asked the barista to try again and said that this was a sign of under-extraction. The second one was better but still pretty horrible without milk.

This morning I had a Gibraltar which had the same problem, so I'm unlikely to return for coffee. Their pastries and snacks, although again horrifically expensive, are of consistently high quality.

$5 espresso drinks need to be perfect every time. That's why you have those 30k machines (yes, I've priced them for opening a business). Four Barrel is a short distance away and it's less expensive and utterly consistent.
author: Seth G.

description: I came in here for a tea and to use the restroom. The gentleman taking my order would not let me use the restroom until I ordered my tea. I told him, that I will order it when I'm done with the restroom. He refused to give me the code until I paid. I was dressed in business attire and in no way did I look homeless. I had to use the restroom soooo bad. The customer service here is terrible and my tea was way over priced @ $7 for a cup. What?!
author: Amanda B.

description:
The folks at Verve always welcome me with warm personal greetings. It always feels like a second home when I'm there. The coffee offerings have ALWAYS been on point for me (and I am not one easily pleased by coffee.)

The Missile is a good caffeine kick in the a$$ (though a little on the sweet side.) The mochas, for me, are perfect. I usually get it iced with non-fat milk and it always comes out perfect. What I do love about their mochas is the rich balance of coffee & mocha flavor and not being overly sweet. 

Lastly, the espresso tonic has been my go-to! I was a bit put off by the mere description of espresso shots in tonic water. I'm SO GLAD my ego wasn't big enough to prevent me from having an open mind. It is refreshing, balanced and still gives that good caffeine kick in the pants!

The combination of a happy palate and welcoming friendly faces makes Verve my go-to spot to start off my day.
author: Theresa D.

description: They are tasty, lots of options of coffee and tea, and delicious pastries. The staff are very nice and can help you pick your drink as there are lot of choices.  The drinks come out rather quickly and are about average to high priced for the area.  But you usually pay between $3-$6 for a cup of good coffee in SF. I would recommend trying this place out!
author: Mandy B.

description:
I love visiting this place in Santa Cruz, its honestly one of my favorite coffee places to visit. When I heard there was one opening in the City I was super happy.

Came here to do some work and see if this Verve was every bit as much as the ones in Santa Cruz. Unfortunately, not so much :( The area of the shop is very big, bright and easy to locate right on the corner of Market and Church. I enjoyed being able to walk right in, find a table and then order up. 

I order the Missile, their strongest coffee drink and it tasted just as I remembered. The right mix of cream, sugar and coffee. Its the best way to go if you're looking for something strong and iced. I also order the Avocado toast. I did enjoy the toast, however I found myself chewing on the stem/pit of the avocado. I know they probably cut these things by hand and made to order but would like a little more care. 

If you're sitting in the area near the bathrooms be prepared to not have any where to charge your laptop. There are no plug in spots in that area, and if there was then I missed it or it was occupied by someone else. The WiFi was also out that day and even though I spent around 2 hours doing work, I had to use my hotspot the whole time even though the bro said it was being fixed. I like Verve, but hope this one can shape up into what I remember about the Santa Cruz locales.
author: John M.

description: Coffee is fine. But the service is shet. Apparently all money goes to the rent of the store and the interior design but not to the employees
author: Maxi C.

description: The coffee/roasting is perfect. Strong, but not bitter. Pastries are also very delish. Well located on market, cute little atmosphere.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Really irritating that there's only 6 chairs. I've been standing here for an hour just waiting for a spot to open up. There's plenty of space, just no tables to work on.

There are cushy seats in the back for reading, etc but as far as doing work there are only 6 seats with a table. Fucking ridiculous.
author: Andreas C.

description:
I ordered macchiato for here to enjoy their cute white cups  but that was made 'to go'. 
Also, it was lukewarm :( :( :(
author: Bidik T.

description: Absolutely A-mazing latte's and avo toast.  The bread was nice and thick, lots of fresh yummy avo with a absolutely refreshing dressing and beet spiral on top.  The presentation of the avo toast itself was enough to impress me! The inside of the establishment is clean, sleek, modern looking.  Fast service and comfortable seating areas to sit alone and do work, peopl-watch or chat with friends. I will definitely come back and try something different.
author: Victoria C.

description:
I was really excited for the San Francisco Verve location to open (being a fan of the Santa Cruz and LA spots), but I was a bit disappointed by this one. The location is very central, corner of Duboce, Castro, and Mission, but they don't have the same cold brew options as the Santa Cruz or LA locations, and they also don't have the juice flights I love so much. Also, their food options are obscenely expensive. I don't mind paying money for a good avo-toast (how can you avoid it in SF?) but $13 seems a bit steep. 

On the flip side, they have some fun options like tea lattes (bowl of soul) and shakeratos (espresso with half and half and house made syrup). They also have Manresa baked treats and a full range of sandwich options. It's also a good place to park and do some work, I really love the bright and colorful interior.
author: Kate M.

description: Strong and creamy cortado.. the foam design was botched, but obviously that's less important. The mid-day vibe feels a lot like one of these new-agey office work spaces. So many laptops, ipads, meetings and phones. Anyway, my coffee was good, fast enough and I'll come back.
author: Derek B.

description:
Boom!  Welcome to the neighborhood. Under permitting and construction for something like 2+ years, despite the range of choices available, it's exciting to have a Verve branch in SF. Their roast is smooth and flavorful and the new setting is bright and contemporary with a couple of nice seating areas.

It'll be packed soon, but this is definitely going to be a regular destination for drinks, pastries and beans.
author: Josh M.

description: The cappuccino was great! Only small complaint is although they seem to have sufficient seating space, it was actually not enough to accommodate the crowd. Would recommend adding a couple more tables.
author: Sharanya A.

description: It's really nice to be in the city just a week after this long anticipated coffee shop opened!  It's a cute hip spot on the corner with a sleek modern look and great lighting from all directions. The baristas are amazing. The pastries look amazing. I wish we got some to eat but we had already got some croissants from the bakery next door. I ordered a cafe au lait and to be honest, it tasted like a regular (little bit light) coffee with milk. For $5, that was quite a lot for me for something that wasn't special. I'd still come back to try something different though.
author: Lilian N.

description: Fabulous fancy coffee with excellent carbs (avocado toast! Biscuit and Jam! Cray yummy cookies). And the employees were nice too - even though crowded and slammed nothing sucked.
author: Catherine C.

description: Great coffee, great service, great space. Severs are super friendly and place runs efficiently.
author: Jon A.

description:
I generally find hipster-ish coffee shops to be oddly intimidating, with weird steampunk brewing contraptions and an ordering process that is wholly undocumented yet seemingly known by everybody but me.

So imagine my surprise when a coffee shop with all the signs of being hipster-ish turned out to be super welcoming. I was greeted as soon as I walked into the door. When I asked about what was in one of the pastries, they happily looked up the ingredients to make double sure there was nothing I was allergic to. And when I was noticeably unsure where to put my used plate and cup, someone came right over and took it for me. Little things, to be sure, but I definitely walked out of there feeling like I was valued as a customer and the staff genuinely cared about the experience of everyone walking in the door.
author: Scott K.

description: Super friendly staff and delicious coffee. Which I'm only about half way through drinking but am so hyper felt inclined to write a review.
author: Emily L.

description: I like the concept of this place. The scene is a real woodsy and contemporary vibe. Even the cash register is made of wood. Very neato. I like it! :) Good stuff!!!
author: Abigail S.

description:
Went to Verve this morning (their first official day of being open). 

Their coffee was great, as I'd expect from Verve. They had one quick cup option, as well as a collection of 4-6 different pour-overs. It's also nice to have a source of Manresa Bread pastries in SF!

I'll have to stop by again and try their prepared food -- I heard something about an avocado toast...
author: Chris M.

description:
Good place in the Castro area to grab some coffee in the afternoon. There are some decadent deserts and basic sandwiches, which isn't always the case with coffee shops. 

Despite the grandness of the space, with high ceilings, big arching windows, a flood of bright light, soothing balance of blue cushions and wood, and plenty of exposed brick, I still felt there was something sterile about this place. It reminded me of Brooklyn, but it wasn't.

Also, the place was too crowded to find a seat at the tables, which are communal, but there's an area in the back with a big U-shaped blue sofa/bench area where fellow coffee drinkers sit side-by-side. 

Not a bad place if you're looking to grab a quick bite/some coffee and read a book/magazine in the back area
author: Behnam S.

description:
Been frequenting here a bit b/c the coffee is far better than Cafe Soleil near my house...

The coffee is great -- refreshing cold brew in chilled glasses, americanos with four shots!

A few complaints though:
- The wifi is nonexistent
- Barista/manager lady always leaves her stuff on the main table, occupying a prime seat for customers
- Skinny cashier guy is awkwardly depressed
- Coffee is pricey. Maybe have a rewards card, or better bring-you-own-mug deal?
author: Alex L.

description: I asked the guy can I have the oatmeal but with no sugar he says sure than I get my oatmeal it taste too good to be true sadly they added sugar they tell me it comes like that will you could have told me from the start I am on diet and that was the point no sugar
author: Karina C.

description: Verve in San Francisco checked off my bucket list the employees in this shop are all baristas who seem like they love their jobs and coffee it's nice to support a business helping people do what they love. Coffee was amazing and latte art was on point
author: Kevin C.

description: Super fresh beans and knowledgeable baristas, right in the heart of Santa Cruz. Will def stop here again next time I'm in town. Was wired for dayz
author: Danny B.

description: Honestly, this might even be a $$$ when you take into account how much coffee will usually cost. I would stop by Verve in Santa Cruz anytime I was down there, as their roasts are usually superb. This place is going to be swamped most times due to serving really good stuff and having a premium location for people who might not work from an office. Still, if you can bear the wait and the lack of seating, you will receive an absolutely delicious cup.
author: Michael H.

description: If you want watered down Starbucks coffee, definitely go here. The service was good, but you also need a good product if you claim to be roasters.
author: Paul R.

description:
Excellent friendly staff who try very hard to please customers! Amazing coffee and food!
Beautiful space!
author: David H.

description: Amazing coffee/espresso. Love the new space that opened in SF. Not as big as the other locations, but glad to have one close by.
author: Matthew B.

description: Very very delicious cappuccino ! Nowhere to sit though. Lots of people on laptops.  And quite pricey too. I bought some verve beans to go.
author: Meredith G.

description: $10 for a small tea and a croissant, are you kidding me? Obviously your rent is too high, and crazy prices is the only way you can support a  café in such a large space. I also had to wait at least 5 to 7 minutes for you to steep my tea for me before giving it to me to go, why? I had to pay more to wait longer, you're doing at least a few things wrong here. Never again.
author: Bobby B.

description:
My coworkers and I have been waiting for verve to open for what feels like ages. A great addition to the area and possibly the best espresso drinks in the city. 

The staff being attentive and friendly is icing on the cake.
author: Otto Z.

description: Biscuits are amazing! So is the ice coffee.
author: Ian R.

description: Overpriced coffee, sticky tables that the staff doesn't seem concerned to clean, and spotty wifi. Plenty of other cafes in the area that speak for themselves, without all the hipster flash and flare of this overrated and underdelivering joint. Pass.
author: Lisa G.

description: Alright, I'm disappointed. This is overpriced coffee by SF standards. Their drip coffee is $4 (!!) and is worse imho than a $1.95 Starbucks drip. Given the number of quality cups you can get for cheaper in SF at Sightglass, Fourbarrel, Blue Bottle, Ritual, Revielle, etc. this aspect is really disappointing for me. They also don't have prices listed for their pastries and their breakfast menu starts at $7, so I'm concerned to ask. The location is great and the place is brand new, but they must be trying to pay their lease off early with the sky high prices.
author: Polina S.

description:
Coffee (see daily menu) *Roast and price not posted
$4 12oz cup of bitter coffee
Can't even be bothered to have cup sleeves
ONLY half & half and one type of sweetener
If you are the 8 coffee shop opening within 6 blocks, you can't be late AND bad in all aspects!
Staff very nice. I hope they find employment elsewhere when this closes.
author: Darren C.

description: Coffee wasn't good and more expensive than your usual expensive coffee. I got the pour over coffee and it was very watery and cold. Although, it's a nice looking place and seems like it would be comfy for studying.
author: Ramin A.

description: We ordered cortados, which were made exactly like they should be made. The staff is always super nice.
author: Norcloud S.

description:
They do not have functioning wifi. 

 Before purchasing I asked directly if they had wifi and the woman at the counter said yes. Then after sitting I asked other employees and they said they didn't have wifi. I don't need wifi if I'm just hanging out and I'm fine if a place does not have wifi. Just let me know at the beginning so I can find a place with wifi.
author: Nnena U.

description: Verve was one of my favorite coffee shops when I lived in LA, so when I heard they had opened one in SF, I was thrilled. Although the quality of their beverages are still on point, their service could use some work. I recently went into verve and ordered  a dozen pastries and a 96oz coffee container. While placing the order, the barista appeared to be annoyed, and made me feel like I was being an inconvenience to him. He wasn't helpful when needing to select pastries, and when ordering the coffee container, he and another coworker told me I would have to wait 30mins to prep the coffee (as if to keep me from ordering it). Overall I felt like my order was a burden, and now feel like this won't be a good option when ordering for a group function.  Hope the service gets better, the longer they are open.
author: Celeste A.

description: I live upstairs from Verve. (The giant diagonal "feature" behind the counter is my stairs.)  I came downstairs this morning to find that February 13, 2017 was Christmas morning!  After a long two-year wait, Verve has finally opened at Church and Market.  I welcome them with open arms as Church/Market has kinda gone downhill since the opening of Twitter at Market/10th pushed all the homeless folks upstream to camp on literally all four corners of our intersection.  Well, with Home restaurant torn down last week, and Verve opening today, I am honestly excited about a little revitalization around here.  Verve's build-out of the former Veo eyewear space is beautifully done, this place looks fantastic.  Verve had only been open for three hours when I visited but obviously had already become a magnet attracting rich late-twentysomethings.  The atmosphere was lively and upbeat, folks sure seem excited about Verve as an addition to the neighborhood.  Since I am basically 100 years old (43), I was the oldest customer in there by far.  I had a $4 ice coffee, plus an $8 poached egg biscuit that was basically tasteless, but beautiful.  There were some minor operational bumps with my ordering process and the wait felt a little long, but nothing that I expect won't be ironed out after they've been open a few days/weeks.  Most of the seating was full and there were probably ten people standing, waiting for orders when I arrived around 9:20AM.  But the standing folks cleared out after just a few minutes.   Staff seemed very friendly and were all smiles.  Not really being a coffeehouse person in general I will probably never go here again as I don't like feeling old and poor, but I am not exaggerating in the slightest when I say I'm thrilled to have them in the neighborhood.
author: Dave M.

description: Good food and pastries, good coffee, good vibe, but it bums me out that they charge $1 more for an americano over an espresso. It's just more water, folks. Also, sometimes the coffee tastes like it was brewed with beans that are less than fresh.
author: Galen P.

description: Might be the best cup of coffee I've ever had. I had the Panama Maria and though very costly ($12), it was so very good. I haven't had anything like it. I'm a coffee junkie, big fan of all the local SF shops but this is the cream of the crop. The staff is AMAZING. The young lady at cashier with short hair is sooooooooooo nice. She walked me through the menu and had the biggest natural smile. The head barista guy is very cool too. Keep it up! Excited to go here. And just outside the muni stops!
author: luis m.

description: Bad location and concept if you need to charge $9.50 for a small coffee and a croissant to support your overhead. The staff are nice and the coffee is decent, but those economics just aren't sustainable. Vacant in two years tops.
author: brian o.

description: Overpriced and underwhelming coffee using cheap ingredients. I've been to many speciality coffee shops in the past decade and I've never seen staff so pressured into fake "friendliness." Not impressed with management when I met her to talk about my experience. I can only assume Verve is trying to make a splash with their expensive location and prices in a bid to attract a corporate buyout. (Just like Stumptown, Intelligentsia and Blue Bottle) Sigh...
author: Davey M.

description: Nice place, perfect location by the muni station but $4 a coffee is so far the most expensive one I have encountered in the city.
author: Sophian A.

description: Great new addition to the neighborhood. The place's already super crowded. Hot chocolate was good but not exceptional. Same for the cookie. Also limited seating space. Overall it feels like a definite step up from the chain coffee shops a la Peet's but not rising quite to the level of the best indie coffee shops.
author: Ruben K.

description: THOROUGHBRED down the street  was closed for the holidays settled for Verve...$10 for a small pastry and small Americano. Not worth it...If you can get Thoroughbread ..their breads/pastries are so much more delicious and fresh and coffee is good.
author: Daisy G.

description: I can't believe I paid $6.50 for a green tea.  I really wanted green tea and this was the only option on the pricey fancy menu.  The tea was great (two stars) but the price is a joke.  Why did it cost that much?  Am I missing something?
author: Wesley W.

description: Hello, this is my first negative review on yelp & I definitely feel bad about writing this, but this place deserves a bad review. I live in the neighborhood, had to go to the bathroom before I got home, decided I might be able to try theirs & the barista rudely told be that I had to be a customer even after I offered to give them a dollar. I just didn't want coffee at 3pm but I love coffee and am a potential customer. But more to the point, what if I had IBS? What if I was homeless? What if I was a lost tourist? This really overpriced coffee shop (which I love usually) moves into a gentrifying neighborhood with really sterile impersonal graphic design, and refuses to give bathroom access to its neighbors. I don't care how good your coffee is, that is pretty terrible. Businesses need to think about being part of the community they serve.
author: Selby C.

description: I too have been waiting a long time for Verve to arrive officially here in The City and it was worth the wait.  Verve is widely known in national coffee circles for their sourcing, quality, attention to detail, showmanship, and top notch baristas. They also do everything with a great sense of style and offer friendly and knowledgeable service. The bean quality is top notch, as is the equipment with which the coffee e is produced. While I enjoy other great quality coffee in town like Ritual, Four Barrel, Equator, Lieana, Blue Bottle, etc, Verve has just upped the game a solid notch with fantastic coffee, service, style, and food. Note that I had the Green Tip Gesha and yes it IS certainly a splurge at $12, unlike some other high $ pour-over/siphon experiences I have had at some other places, this one was indeed truly unique and worth it in my opinion.  Welcome to San Francisco at long last Verve!
author: Lance W.

description: Minus one star for trying to convince me that 12 dollars for a cup of coffee is really not that much . I really like Verve, I've bought all their Geishas over the years... but seriously just try to keep it real... smile.. keep up the good work.. I'll keep coming back..
author: Demanding T.

description: After searching this city for bright, airy cafes complete with great drinks and big wooden tables over the past year and a half since I moved here, I have FINALLY found my home base! This is a perfect of my two favorite working spaces in NYC: Barnes & Noble and Grace Street. I just bring my own books now. :)
author: Jane Z.

description: All the cool kids go here, but I think they had a party to get to because I was allowed in. Despite me bringing down the vibe completely, the place still was all sorts of hip and the iced latte was awesome sauce (please note: the latte wasn't actually sauce, it's just an expression).
author: Ryan S.

description: San Francisco is crazy if they think blue bottle is better than verve. This roaster is awesome I use to drive from the east bay to Santa Cruz to get their coffee. I just s hope they don't sell out like blue bottle and stumptown
author: Jessica S.

description:
3.5 stars

A Santa Cruz import.  The cafe is thoughtfully designed with a modern, airy, beachy vibe.  A little light on the seating options/availability.  I sat on one of the padded benches and was surprised there weren't any outlets around to plug my laptop into - so that foiled my work plan.  Also surprising was how dirty the two coffee tables were.  There were at least 20-30 coffee rings on them that could have been remedied with a quick wipe.

So what about the coffee?  My go-to litmus test when trying out a new cafe is to order a mocha.  A bit of sticker shock when the tab came to just under $6.  But whatever, figured I'd give it a try.  The wait time was rather extended, considering I was the only one in line.  After at least 5 minutes, the barista finally slid a drink onto the counter, but told me it wasn't mine.  It was for someone sitting down.  Oh ok, so service is a little slow.  It's new.  I can cut them some slack.  So I waited awhile more.  Then the next drink came up.  Also not for me - for another seated patron.  So I waited some more, thinking wow, they're really taking this coffee-crafting thing seriously.  Finally!  After prob 10-12 min total, I had my mocha.  

Settled into my seat, took a sip.  Texture-wise, it was prob the best I've ever had (and I've not really ever thought about the textures of my mochas before) -- smooth, creamy, silky.  Very nice.  Chocolate flavor was a bit mild - I prefer more of a bittersweet flavor (like at Peet's).  Not very hot (which actually worked for me, but prob not for most ppl).  Overall, a solid, enjoyable mocha.  

I won't rush back as there isn't enough seating & no outlets.  And it's $$$.  But if I was in the area & in need of a special treat, I'd venture in again and give it another try.
author: Jason P.

description: This place is right off the BART station and wasn't too crowded on the afternoon I went. The cozy seating around the window makes for a ra great area for hanging out and chatting, while the table area is great for work. I liked how the two were separated so you don't get distracted by chatter if you're trying to focus. I really appreciated the openness of the space and the ample natural lighting. Baristas were friendly and welcoming!
author: Karen J.

description: Nice little shop. I have mad respect for SC guys opening up a shop in SF where so many SF-based cafes exist. I've always enjoyed their coffee and pastries when visiting SC so nice to see a familiar brand of high caliber down the street from me now. Great Gibraltar and gluten free pastry this morning. Was served super quickly and was treated kindly by everyone working. Only downside is a little lack of seating that's not community style. Keep up the good work!
author: Ryan D.

description: Stopped in the day before they opened (I thought they already had) and tried to buy some coffee. Was first turned away, then chased down the block and given a free sample. Customer for life.
author: Breena K.

description:
Verve has been one of my favorite place to grab coffee, ever since discovering them a few years ago in Santa Cruz.  There Flavored Latte is amazing.  I was psyched to find they opened in SF.

The staff this morning was very friendly.  

My only complaint about the SF Verve is they only have one size for their lattes, 12oz (and I think all of their drinks).  Please provide a Large option.
author: Brent A.

description: Bright, cheery, hip. Excellent lattes. Expensive food. Eager to please staff who are appropriately quirky. Hope they stay that way.
author: Robert S.

description:
The coffee on tap was your typical light roast citric bomb without much real flavor to speak of. Definitely none of the fig called out in the tasting notes. The food seems crazy expensive, $7.50 for a small cup of oats with a fan of apple on top. I dare you to eat that with a spoon. 
The streetlevel espresso tasted like all the other trendy SF coffee shops - thin and sour and boring. 
It has a nice layout, but the uninspired styling inside feels like Starbucks meets McDonald's. The staff was over the top faux-sincere with their "toootally" and "awesome" lattes, typical verve friendliness. They really pumped out some drinks, though, so I gotta say they are fast. A little bummed to see who I presume was the manager pacing and phone checking and computer glaring so intensely behind the bar. 
While I've always had a strange soft spot for verve, I've only once had their coffee taste good in any of their cafes I've been to. I'll go back one or two more times, but realistically it'll be another cafe to file away in SF's boring, homogeneous coffee experience.
author: Mark B.

description: I've been drinking Verve Street Level espresso for over a year. Never had it prepared by Verve themselves and today was my lucky day, it was awesome! Their SF location on market street is beautiful and super clean so i love it.
author: Yazz A.

description: A+ spot. Been waiting for a while for this gem to open, and it was well worth the wait. Ryan and Nathan are awesome, and the coffee speaks for itself- definitely swing by here the next chance you get!
author: SR S.
